definitions: have an effect on the character, development, or behavior of someone or something
use one's power or position to persuade someone to act in a particular way
examples: Social media can strongly influence young people's opinions about fashion
The weather will influence our decision about the outdoor wedding
She tried to influence the committee to support her proposal
Parents naturally influence their children's values and beliefs

definitions: go up or ascend something using hands and feet or with effort and difficulty
increase in amount, value, or level over a period of time
examples: The children love to climb trees in the backyard
We had to climb steep stairs to reach the temple
Gas prices continue to climb despite government intervention efforts
The company's stock price climbed steadily throughout the year

definitions: bring something to an end or finish a meeting, speech, or piece of writing
arrive at a judgment or decision by reasoning from evidence or premises
examples: The professor concluded the lecture with an inspiring quote
We'll conclude today's meeting after reviewing the budget
The detective concluded that the suspect had an alibi
Scientists concluded the experiment was successful after analyzing data

definitions: give a long, loud, piercing cry expressing extreme emotion or pain
be very obvious or noticeable in an emphatic or startling way
examples: She screamed when she saw the spider on her pillow
The fans screamed with excitement when their team scored
The headlines screamed about the political scandal on every newspaper
Her bright red dress screamed for attention at the party

definitions: cover a surface with paint to protect or decorate it using brushes or tools
describe or depict someone or something in a particular way using words
examples: We need to paint the bedroom walls before moving in
The artist painted beautiful landscapes of the countryside
The media painted him as a hero after the rescue
Her memoir paints a vivid picture of life during wartime

definitions: express dissatisfaction or annoyance about something, often repeatedly or to someone in authority
examples: Customers often complain about the slow internet service at hotels
She complained to the manager about the noisy neighbors

definitions: lower and raise one's head slightly and briefly in greeting, assent, or understanding
give approval or permission through a gesture or informal agreement
examples: She nodded politely when introduced to her new colleagues
He nodded his head to the rhythm of the music
The committee finally nodded the proposal through after long discussions
The referee nodded to indicate the goal was valid

definitions: claim that someone has done something wrong or illegal, often without definite proof
examples: The employee accused her boss of discrimination in the workplace
They accused him of stealing money from the company safe

definitions: strike a surface noisily to attract attention, especially when waiting to enter
find fault with or criticize someone or something, especially unfairly
examples: Please knock on the door before entering my office
The delivery person knocked three times but nobody answered
Critics always knock her movies without watching them properly
Don't knock it until you've actually tried it yourself

definitions: be equal to something in quality, strength, or another measurable characteristic
put together or bring into competition things that correspond or are suitable
examples: No other athlete could match her speed on the track
The results didn't match our expectations for the project
We need to match the paint color to the existing walls
The dating app matches people based on shared interests

definitions: risk money or something valuable on the outcome of an uncertain event
express confidence that something is true or will happen without absolute certainty
examples: He bet fifty dollars on his favorite horse to win
Many people bet on football games during the season
I bet she'll arrive late to the meeting again
You can bet it will rain during our vacation

definitions: refer to something as evidence or justification for an argument or statement
officially order someone to appear in court for breaking a law or regulation
examples: Students must cite all sources in their research papers properly
The lawyer cited several precedents to support her case
The officer cited him for speeding in a school zone
The restaurant was cited for multiple health code violations

definitions: follow or chase someone or something in order to catch or attack them
continue to investigate, explore, or work steadily toward achieving a particular aim
examples: The police pursued the suspect through the crowded streets
The cat pursued the mouse around the kitchen
She decided to pursue a career in medical research
The company will pursue new opportunities in emerging markets

definitions: ask someone something in order to obtain information or elicit a response
feel or express doubt about something or challenge its accuracy or validity
examples: The detective questioned witnesses about what they saw
Students should question the teacher if something is unclear
Many people question the effectiveness of the new policy
She began to question her decision to move abroad

definitions: roughly calculate or judge the value, number, quantity, or extent of something
examples: The contractor will estimate the cost of renovating the kitchen
We estimate that 200 people will attend the conference

definitions: make a number of connected items or names written or printed consecutively
lean over to one side, typically of a ship or building
examples: Please list all the ingredients needed for the recipe
The teacher asked students to list their favorite books
The old ship began to list dangerously in rough seas
The damaged building lists to the left after the earthquake

definitions: express an opinion or reaction about something verbally or in writing
examples: She commented on how beautiful the garden looked this year
Readers can comment on articles below each blog post

definitions: put money into financial schemes, property, or a commercial venture to gain profit
devote time, effort, or energy to a particular undertaking with expectation of results
examples: They decided to invest in technology stocks for retirement
Many people invest in real estate for long-term gains
Parents invest considerable time in their children's education
The company will invest heavily in employee training programs

definitions: make something visible by uncovering it or putting it in an unprotected situation
reveal the true, often unfavorable nature of someone or something to public view
examples: Don't expose the film to direct sunlight before developing
The low tide exposed hidden rocks along the shore
The journalist exposed corruption in the local government office
The investigation exposed serious flaws in the system

definitions: fasten or secure something with a lock to prevent access or theft
become fixed in one position and unable to move or function normally
examples: Remember to lock the door when you leave the house
She locked her bicycle to the rack outside
The computer screen locked up and wouldn't respond
His jaw locked from the tension during the interview

definitions: cause someone to believe firmly in the truth of something through argument or evidence
examples: The lawyer tried to convince the jury of her client's innocence
It took months to convince him to see a doctor

definitions: acquire something by paying for it with money in a formal or business context
examples: They decided to purchase a new car for the family
The company will purchase new equipment for the factory

definitions: address a prayer to God or another deity, often asking for help or expressing thanks
wish or hope strongly for a particular outcome or situation to occur
examples: Many people pray before meals to give thanks
She prayed for her son's safe return from war
We're praying for good weather on our wedding day
I pray that the test results come back negative

definitions: used to indicate duty or correctness, typically when criticizing someone's actions or giving advice
examples: You ought to apologize for your rude behavior yesterday
Children ought to respect their elders and teachers

definitions: break free from confinement or control by fleeing or getting out of a place
avoid or succeed in not experiencing something unpleasant or unwanted
examples: The prisoner managed to escape from jail during the night
The family escaped from the burning building just in time
She reads novels to escape the stress of daily life
We barely escaped having to pay a huge fine

definitions: completely remove or get rid of something unwanted or unnecessary from a system or process
examples: The new software will eliminate errors in data processing
We need to eliminate waste to improve company efficiency

definitions: combine or put together two or more substances so that they form one substance
associate with others socially or participate in social activities with different people
examples: Mix the flour and eggs together to make pasta dough
The bartender mixed several ingredients to create the cocktail
She finds it hard to mix with people at parties
Students from different cultures mix freely on campus

definitions: put a decision, plan, or agreement into effect by taking concrete actions to achieve it
examples: The school will implement new safety procedures next month
It takes time to implement changes in large organizations

definitions: officially agree to or accept something as satisfactory after consideration or examination
have a favorable opinion of someone or something and support their actions
examples: The board must approve all major budget changes
The city council approved plans for the new park
Her parents don't approve of her career choice
Most voters approve of the governor's performance

definitions: lose one's footing and slide unintentionally for a short distance
move somewhere quietly, quickly, or secretly without being noticed
gradually worsen or fall to a lower level, standard, or position
examples: She slipped on the icy sidewalk and hurt her knee
Be careful not to slip on the wet floor
He slipped out of the meeting without anyone noticing
She slipped the letter into his coat pocket
Sales have slipped by 10 percent this quarter
Don't let your grades slip during senior year

definitions: be without or have an insufficient quantity or quality of something needed or wanted
examples: The proposal lacks concrete details about implementation costs
Many rural schools lack basic educational resources

definitions: communicate with someone by phone, letter, email, or other means to exchange information
examples: Please contact customer service if you have any problems
I'll contact you next week about the job interview

definitions: touch with the lips as a sign of love, greeting, or reverence
examples: Parents kiss their children goodnight before tucking them in
The couple kissed under the mistletoe at Christmas

definitions: fill someone with the urge or ability to do or feel something positive
create a feeling or thought in someone that leads to artistic or creative work
examples: Her courage inspired others to stand up for their rights
Great teachers inspire students to achieve their dreams
The beautiful sunset inspired him to write a poem
Nature often inspires artists to create masterpieces

definitions: point or direct a weapon, camera, or other object at a particular target
have the intention of achieving a particular goal or reaching a specific outcome
examples: The archer aimed carefully at the center of the target
She aimed the telescope at the brightest star
We aim to finish the project by next Friday
The company aims to reduce carbon emissions by half

definitions: dismiss as inadequate, inappropriate, or not to one's taste by refusing to accept or consider
examples: The editor rejected her manuscript without giving specific reasons
The committee rejected all proposals that exceeded the budget

definitions: give someone facts or information about something in a formal or official way
examples: Please inform all employees about the new safety procedures
The doctor will inform you of the test results tomorrow

definitions: throw something forcefully in a specified direction with deliberate motion
select actors to play particular parts in a play, movie, or show
shape metal or other material by pouring it into a mold while liquid
examples: The fisherman cast his line far into the lake
She cast the dice and hoped for good luck
The director will cast the lead role next week
They cast unknown actors in all the major parts
The artist cast the bronze sculpture in her studio
Workers cast concrete blocks for the new building

definitions: cease work or movement in order to relax, refresh oneself, or recover strength
remain or be left in a specified condition, position, or state after others have gone
examples: You should rest after such a long journey
The doctor told him to rest for several days
The decision rests with the board of directors
Her hopes rest on getting the scholarship

definitions: consider or regard something in a specified way when making a calculation or decision
give a satisfactory explanation or reason for one's actions or whereabouts
examples: The survey accounts for differences in regional preferences
This factor accounts for most of the price increase
He couldn't account for his absence from the meeting
Can you account for all the money that was spent

definitions: choose someone to hold public office or position by voting in a formal process
examples: Citizens will elect a new president next November
The board elected her as the new committee chair

definitions: perceive or detect the odor or scent of something using the nose
emit an odor or scent that can be perceived by the sense of smell
examples: I can smell fresh bread baking in the oven
Dogs can smell things humans cannot detect
The flowers smell wonderful in the spring garden
Something smells bad in the refrigerator

definitions: pick up and give something to someone using one's hand in a physical transfer
help someone to achieve something or assist them in some way
examples: Could you hand me that book from the shelf
She handed the cashier exact change for her purchase
You have to hand it to her for trying
The coach really handed them the victory

definitions: evaluate or estimate the nature, quality, ability, or value of something systematically
examples: Teachers assess student progress through regular tests and assignments
The insurance company will assess the damage to your car

definitions: have an idea or impression of something without certain proof but think it probable
doubt the genuineness or truth of something based on evidence or intuition
examples: Police suspect he was involved in the robbery
I suspect she knows more than she's telling us
I suspect his motives for helping us so generously
Many people suspect the accuracy of those statistics

definitions: come down through the air and alight on the ground or another surface
succeed in obtaining or achieving something desirable, especially after effort
examples: The plane will land at the airport in twenty minutes
The bird landed on the branch outside my window
She finally landed her dream job at the company
The actor landed the lead role after many auditions

definitions: give work to someone and pay them for it in a formal arrangement
make use of something as a means of achieving a purpose or result
examples: The factory employs over 500 workers from the area
They plan to employ more staff during the holiday season
The teacher employs various methods to keep students engaged
Scientists employ advanced technology in their research

definitions: make a short, sharp sound like that of a switch being operated
press a button on a computer mouse or touchpad to select something
suddenly become clear or understood, often after a period of confusion
examples: The door clicked shut behind her as she left
I heard her heels click on the marble floor
Click the link to download the file
Just click on the icon to open the program
Everything suddenly clicked when she explained the concept differently
It finally clicked why he had been acting strange

definitions: repeat or copy the exact words from a text or speech, giving acknowledgment to the source
state the current price of something or estimate the cost of a job or service
examples: The professor likes to quote Shakespeare in her lectures
Don't quote me on this, but I heard they're engaged
The mechanic will quote a price for repairing your car
Can you quote me for installing new windows

definitions: give someone or something the authority, means, or opportunity to do something
examples: This software enables users to edit photos easily
The new law will enable citizens to vote online
